_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Belridge Gas Plant is located on 19718 Gustafson Dr., which is approximately 2.0 miles west of Highway 33, on the southwest end of Contractor Road in McKittrick, CA.



The Belridge Gas Plant has developed a risk management program to address the EPA RMP Program requirements (Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Plan (RMP) 40 CFR ?68).  The facility is diligent in the handling of all chemicals and dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community.  The facility's staff is trained and utilizes equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely storing, processing, and extracting natural gas liquids. This is an RMP Program 3 facility.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Belridge Gas Plant has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, the operation, and the maintenance of the Natural Gas Liquid Extraction system.  The Belridge Gas Plant's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The facility processes natural gas and extracts, stores and transfers propane, butane, and natural gasoline to LPG transport vehicles. There are seven tanks with a total capacity of 370,292 gallons, the largest of which is 68,931 gallons. The storage levels on all seven tanks are administratively controlled not to exceed 90% of each tank's maximum capacity. The Belridge Gas Plant currently uses approximately 1,800,000 lbs of total flammable materials in the tanks and associated equipment. 



The system is composed of the following key equipment/systems:

-Gas Compression system

-Inlet Gas system

-Refrigeration Compressor system

-Ethylene Glycol system

-Deethanizer system

-Depropanizer system

-Debutanizer system

-Butane Splitter system

-Instrument Air system

-Flare system

-PLC system

-Loading Rack system

-Fuel Gas system

-Hot Oil system



HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFF SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary:

Scenario Description: Per the CalARP Regulations, one flammable worst-case analysis has been defined for the Natural Gas Liquid Extraction.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the Compliance Workbook.  



Alternative Release Scenarios Results Summary:

Scenario Description: A realistic flammable alternative release scenario was modeled utilizing a transfer hose failure scenario.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the Compliance Workbook. 



Off-site Receptors

RMP requirements state that sensitive populations such as schools, hospitals, day-care centers, long-term health care facilities, prisons, residential areas, public use parks/recreational areas, and major commercial facilities, located within the "at risk" area must be identified.  These sensitive populations include individuals who could not remove themselves from the exposure area without assistance.  The sensitive populations also include industrial installations which may have a hazardous process that cannot be immediately left unattended. Only major industrial facilities were identified as part of the Hazard Assessments.   



Risk Considerations

Although the storage and extraction of natural gas has inherent potential risks, and a worst-case release scenarios will not reach a community; the Belridge Gas Plant has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions tha

t make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.

 

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a flammable mixture release:

-The system has alarms

-The system undergoes periodic maintenance to reduce the likelihood of catastrophic failures

-Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is used by plant personnel, as necessary

-The system has interlocks and emergency shutdowns

-The system has relief valves and rupture discs

-The system has a Flare system

-The system has Emergency power

-The system has Scrubbers

-The Facility has a deluge system

-Excess flow devices are used

-The facility has Gas detectors



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

As part of the implementation of this RMP Program, key Prevention Program elements were implemented by Belridge Gas Plant to manage process safety issues associated with the storage and extraction of natural gasses.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.

The flammable material Prevention Program 3 elements include:

- Process Safety Information

- Process Hazard Analysis

- Operating Procedures

- Training

- Mechanical Integrity

- Management of Change

- Pre-Startup Safety Review

- Compliance Audits

- Incident Investigation

- Employee Participation

- Hot Work Permit

- Contractors

- Emergency Planning and Response



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no RMP-applicable releases of flammable materials at the facility in at least the past five (5) years. 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Seneca Resources Corporation maintains an emergency response plan in compliance with local emergency response agencies. The Belridge Gas Plant h

as a Hazardous Materials Business Plan uploaded into the California Environmental Reporting System (CERS).  The Kern County Environmental Health Department has access to CERS. The facility maintains an air pollution control district permit to operate with the San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District, Permit S-1242.
